ygData.msgSnippet: ... That seems strange to me.  It seems to me like the more appropriate thing to do is to limit mutations to one structural change at a time.  You can add one

>From: Derek James <djames@...>
>
>On Fri, 04 Jun 2004 00:42:41 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@...> 
>wrote:
> > Consider the problem from the other direction then. If all of of these
> > useless structures aren't participating positively in a search (on the
> > whole) then every single improvement seen in a population must come from
> > immediately beneficial single mutations.
>
>Well, that's not entirely accurate.  In any new individual generated
>in NEAT, there could be a very large number of mutations at once.
>Many of its connection weights may be mutated at once, along with the
>addition (or subtraction) of a fairly large number of topological
>features.

That seems strange to me.  It seems to me like the more appropriate thing to 
do is to limit mutations to one structural change at a time.  You can add 
one connection, OR you can split one connection (or delete one 
connection...), but you can't do any more than that for a given mutation of 
a given organism.  Then, each and every change has a chance to prove itself 
before being added upon.

> > So anyway, what I was proposing was a method of getting the best of both
> > worlds. If excess structure is important then keep it, but if the search
> > has stagnated for a period of time then I would say that the excess
> > structures have now had plenty of time to prove themselves - and failed.
> > They have crossed the line from being possible useful structures into
> > being useless junk (bloat).
>
>It would be interesting to see if this view could be tested
>empirically.  It was my understanding that the philosophy of NEAT was
>essentially gradualist in its approach to adding structure, and that
>was part of the appeal of it to me.  It sounds as if you and Ken are
>both now arguing more for the approach of jumping, via allowing chunks
>of untested morphology to accumulate in the hope that they will
>eventually spontaneously contribute to increased fitness.

I don't think that's what Ken was trying to say.

Picture an experiment.  Focus on one species that is fairly well developed, 
but stagnant.  During a generation, the top members breed or are mutated.  
The mutations add structure.  Some are helpful, maybe.  Some hinder.  Others 
are neutral.  Those that are a hindrence get selected against.  Those that 
help are selected for.  But in (this) stagnant population, few single 
mutations are by themselves helpful.  So a lot of the neutral mutations 
survive to the next generation.  They are now carrying something extra.  It 
doesn't help.  It doesn't hinder.  It's just there.

At the next generation, the same thing happens.  Now, some portion of the 
population will not have any extra, some will have one extra, and others 
will have two.  And others will be mixtures thereof.  If that isn't enough 
to cause a fitness jump, then the process happens again.  Again, some will 
have no extra, some one extra, some two, some three, and many will be 
variants thereof.  The more generations go by, the bigger the spectrum.  
However, it will most likely be fairly evenly distributed between those 
without and those with extra neutral structure.

As that neutral structure is recombined through crossover, some will be a 
hindrence, and will die out.  Others might be helpful, and others neutral, 
same as with mutation.  If no helpful ones are discovered, then neutral will 
remain.

Eventually, some combination may strike on a configuration that results in 
an improvement in fitness.  At that point, evolution will favor that 
configuration.  The stagnation will end.  The point is, to get there, you 
had to add structure.  There's no assurance that all the 'extraneous' 
structure that accumulated will be useful, however.

As for the idea of pruning a stagnant species, that's not all that 
good...when you start going forward again, you would undo your pruning as 
you look for a way to move forward.  You would need to wait until the 
stagnant species has broken out of that stagnation, and THEN prune.  But I 
think your best bet is to wait until you have found an acceptable solution, 
and then do a phase that supports pruning in order to optimize that 
solution.
